We are excited to start our school year with 5 new staff members. Meet our new middle level Social Studies teacher, Mr. David Cassleman:

"I'm very excited to be joining the Peninsula School community this year! My wife is a native Mainer, but I was born and raised in Michigan – and only moved to the east coast in 2019. Teaching is my second career: I spent several years working as a public radio host and reporter in northern Michigan, before deciding to go back to school to become a teacher. I still love to follow the news and look forward to discussing current events with all my students. I believe social studies class should be a time to discover connections between what's happened in the past and what's happening today in our world. Outside of school, I enjoy exploring the outdoors, cross-country skiing and playing guitar."

Updated guidelines from Maine Department of Education are expected July 31st. These guidelines will greatly impact our plan for school re-entry.
While we are not yet ready to share our draft plan (please stay tuned. We are getting closer), we do know that the following practices will be required of all staff and students who are in our building:
~Students (parents/caregivers) and staff must conduct self-checks for symptoms before getting on the bus or entering the school building each day. Symptomatic individuals are expected to stay home.
~Adults and students will need to wear face coverings in the school building and on the school bus.
~Adults must maintain 6' physical distancing. Students must maintain at least 3' physical distancing when wearing face coverings and 6' physical distancing when eating or drinking (at which point they would not be wearing face coverings).
Thank you for your continued patience as we work to ensure the safety of our students and staff.

Regional School Unit No. 24 added 85 new photos to the album: RSU 24 Shellfish Project On-Site Research — in Corea, Maine.
October 3, 2019 · Corea, ME ·

RSU 24 Middle Level students from all four schools have been identified as Student Ambassadors for an ongoing Shellfish Investigation project in conjunction with the SMHS Pathways Students, the Schoodic Institute, local Shellfish Committees, and the Department of Marine Resources. On October 3, middle-level Student Ambassadors along with SMHS Pathways mentors collected data about how many green crabs were present in specific plots on a mud flat in Corea, Maine. The real-word research will be analyzed and used by the Schoodic Institute, the DMR, and the Shellfish Committees to inform important decisions about clam seeding and other actions. Project-based learning at it's finest!!
